query: To improve soil fertility, how does adding compost compare to adding manure?
relevant_summary: Across replicated, controlled studies, adding compost often increased soil organic matter in some or all comparisons (12 studies) [1362], while adding manure increased organic matter in some studies but not others [1363]. Compost increased soil nutrients in some or all comparisons in several studies, with inconsistent nitrogen responses and no phosphorus difference in one USA study; pH was often similar [1362]. Manure increased nitrogen in some comparisons, potassium in two studies, and showed mixed results for phosphorus and pH [1363]. Compost frequently increased microbial biomass in some or all comparisons, with some studies showing no difference and shifts in bacterial communities [1362]; manure showed similar microbial biomass to controls in two studies [1363], whereas other studies reported higher microbial biomass or respiration when manure or compost was applied [911]. Both compost and manure were associated with reduced erosion and/or higher soil stability in some studies [1362, 1363], and one study found lower soil loss and runoff when manure was applied with other treatments [911]. Greenhouse gas responses differed: compost sometimes increased emissions and sometimes showed no difference across studies [1362], while manure increased carbon dioxide and nitrous oxide emissions in individual studies [1363]. In nutrient retention and loss, one trial reported reduced nutrient loss and higher nitrogen with farmyard or poultry manure, though another found higher nitrate leaching [911]; a trial applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure improved soil structure and reduced soil loss but increased nutrient loss [891]. Several studies found higher crop yields when manures or compost were applied [911].

query: For arable fields in the Mediterranean, how does a no-tillage system compare with a reduced tillage system for improving soil health?
relevant_summary: Across Mediterranean studies, both no-tillage and reduced tillage often increased soil organic matter compared to conventional tillage: meta-analyses from Mediterranean countries and multiple studies from Spain and Italy reported higher organic matter under no-tillage, and another meta-analysis from multiple Mediterranean countries reported higher organic matter under reduced tillage [1369, 1371]. For nutrients, Mediterranean evidence was mixed for both practices: under no-tillage, studies from Italy, Spain, and Portugal found more nitrogen in some comparisons and less in others, and phosphorus was sometimes higher and sometimes lower; under reduced tillage, studies from Italy and Spain reported more nitrogen or phosphorus in some comparisons, with other studies in Spain and Syria finding similar or lower nitrogen in some cases [1369, 1371]. Soil biological responses were also mixed but frequently positive: no-tillage increased microbial biomass in some studies from Italy and Spain, with other Spanish studies finding similar or lower biomass; reduced tillage similarly showed increases in microbial biomass in some studies from Italy and Spain, with some Spanish and Syrian studies reporting similar or lower biomass [1369, 1371]. Soil structure tended to improve under both systems in Mediterranean contexts but with variability: no-tillage commonly produced more stable soils in Spain (with some mixed results), while reduced tillage in Spain increased aggregate water-stability or large aggregates in some comparisons, with other studies reporting similar or lower stability [1369, 1371]. Regarding water-related soil health indicators, no-tillage in Spain often increased soil water content and improved water-use efficiency for barley in some comparisons; reduced tillage in Egypt and Spain often increased soil water content and improved crop water-use efficiency in Spain and Turkey, though Lebanon studies reported lower water content under both practices in some comparisons [1384, 1386]. Greenhouse gas fluxes relevant to soil processes showed mixed outcomes in Mediterranean studies for both practices, with some Spanish and Italian studies finding higher or lower CO2 under no-tillage, and Spanish studies reporting higher, lower, or similar CO2 and N2O under reduced tillage [1369, 1371]. Overall, Mediterranean evidence indicates both no-tillage and reduced tillage can improve aspects of soil health relative to conventional tillage, with direction and magnitude varying by indicator and study [1369, 1371, 1384, 1386].

Soil organisms (16 studies)

Nutrients (0 studies)
Sediments (0 studies)


Implementation options (2 studies): One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Egypt found more water and faster water infiltration rates in soils that were tilled at slower tractor speeds, but found that water losses and water-use efficiencies were similar in plots that were tilled at different tractor speeds. tools_called.args: {"query":"For arable fields in the Mediterranean, how does a no-tillage system compare with a reduced tillage system for improving soil health?","summary":"Across Mediterranean studies, both no-tillage and reduced tillage often increased soil organic matter compared to conventional tillage: meta-analyses from Mediterranean countries and multiple studies from Spain and Italy reported higher organic matter under no-tillage, and another meta-analysis from multiple Mediterranean countries reported higher organic matter under reduced tillage [1369, 1371]. For nutrients, Mediterranean evidence was mixed for both practices: under no-tillage, studies from Italy, Spain, and Portugal found more nitrogen in some comparisons and less in others, and phosphorus was sometimes higher and sometimes lower; under reduced tillage, studies from Italy and Spain reported more nitrogen or phosphorus in some comparisons, with other studies in Spain and Syria finding similar or lower nitrogen in some cases [1369, 1371]. Soil biological responses were also mixed but frequently positive: no-tillage increased microbial biomass in some studies from Italy and Spain, with other Spanish studies finding similar or lower biomass; reduced tillage similarly showed increases in microbial biomass in some studies from Italy and Spain, with some Spanish and Syrian studies reporting similar or lower biomass [1369, 1371]. Soil structure tended to improve under both systems in Mediterranean contexts but with variability: no-tillage commonly produced more stable soils in Spain (with some mixed results), while reduced tillage in Spain increased aggregate water-stability or large aggregates in some comparisons, with other studies reporting similar or lower stability [1369, 1371]. Regarding water-related soil health indicators, no-tillage in Spain often increased soil water content and improved water-use efficiency for barley in some comparisons; reduced tillage in Egypt and Spain often increased soil water content and improved crop water-use efficiency in Spain and Turkey, though Lebanon studies reported lower water content under both practices in some comparisons [1384, 1386]. Greenhouse gas fluxes relevant to soil processes showed mixed outcomes in Mediterranean studies for both practices, with some Spanish and Italian studies finding higher or lower CO2 under no-tillage, and Spanish studies reporting higher, lower, or similar CO2 and N2O under reduced tillage [1369, 1371]. Overall, Mediterranean evidence indicates both no-tillage and reduced tillage can improve aspects of soil health relative to conventional tillage, with direction and magnitude varying by indicator and study [1369, 1371, 1384, 1386].","action_ids":["1369","1371","1384","1386"]}

query: What are the potential drawbacks for crop production when planting ground cover in Mediterranean orchards or vineyards?
relevant_summary:
- In French vineyards, seeding grass between vine rows reduced grape yields compared to bare soil in some or all comparisons [1352].
- In Portuguese chestnut orchards, seeded cover crops produced lower chestnut yields than resident vegetation; one study also reported smaller chestnuts and lower mushroom yields with seeded cover crops [1352].
- In Portugal, plots with seeded cover crops had fewer mushrooms and fewer mushroom species than plots with resident vegetation [1413].

query: What does the evidence say about how adding different organic amendments to soil affects greenhouse gas emissions on Mediterranean farmland?
relevant_summary: Across Mediterranean studies, adding slurry to soil was associated with higher nitrous oxide emissions in most comparisons, higher carbon dioxide in some comparisons, and either reduced methane absorption or no change in methane fluxes (Spain) [1365]. Using organic fertilizers instead of inorganic ones often increased carbon dioxide emissions (Italy, Spain), led to similar or greater methane absorption depending on the study (Spain), and resulted in similar or lower nitrous oxide emissions, with a meta-analysis reporting lower nitrous oxide after solid organic fertilizers compared to inorganic fertilizers [1366]. Adding sewage sludge increased carbon dioxide emissions (Spain, USA) [1364]. Adding manure increased carbon dioxide emissions (USA) and increased nitrous oxide emissions (Spain) [1363]. An implementation comparison reported that plots with slurry absorbed methane while plots with manure emitted methane (Spain) [1366].

query: How do additions of compost, manure, and slurry compare in their effects on soil organic matter and nutrients in Mediterranean farmland?
relevant_summary: In Mediterranean contexts, applying manure or compost increased soil organic matter and improved soil physical properties in a replicated, randomized study from Turkey (manure and compost) [911]. For slurry, studies from Spain and multiple Mediterranean countries found similar soil organic matter with or without slurry in most cases, though one replicated, randomized study in Spain reported higher organic matter with slurry in some comparisons [1365]. Regarding nutrients, studies from Spain reported reduced nutrient loss and higher soil nitrogen when manure was applied [911]. For slurry, replicated, randomized studies from Spain and Portugal reported mixed effects on soil nitrate (higher in some Spanish studies; similar in others) and inconsistent effects on ammonium (one Spanish study higher; another similar) [1365]. Comparing compost and manure directly, a study from Italy found plots fertilized with compost had more soil organic matter, nutrients, and microbial biomass than those with manure [1366]. With compost additions, Mediterranean studies also reported greater nutrients (nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium) and organic matter in runoff from Spanish plots, and greater nitrate leaching in one of four comparisons in Portugal [1377].

{"query":"How do additions of compost, manure, and slurry compare in their effects on soil organic matter and nutrients in Mediterranean farmland?","summary":"In Mediterranean contexts, applying manure or compost increased soil organic matter and improved soil physical properties in a replicated, randomized study from Turkey (manure and compost) [911]. Comparing compost and manure directly, a study from Italy found plots fertilized with compost had more soil organic matter, nutrients, and microbial biomass than those with manure [1366]. query: What are the effects of excluding grazing animals on plant biodiversity in grasslands and shrublands in Mediterranean climates?
relevant_summary: Across studies in Mediterranean-region countries (Israel and Spain) and focusing on grasslands and shrublands, excluding livestock has shown mixed effects on plant biodiversity: some studies reported more species or fewer non‑native species in exclosures compared to grazed areas in some or all comparisons [2292; 1417]. Other studies in grasslands and shrublands reported fewer species or fewer native species, or smaller increases in species numbers, when grazers were excluded, in some comparisons [2292; 1417]. Some studies in shrublands found no difference in plant diversity between exclosures and grazed plots [2292; 1417]. In some cases, plant diversity was higher, or plant community composition differed, in plots with cattle excluded compared to grazed plots, in some comparisons [2292; 1417].

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
Amphibians (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled study in wet grasslands in the USA found no difference in the abundance of Yosemite toads between areas with cattle excluded and grazed areas.
Birds (2 studies): One replicated site comparison in desert in the USA found more bird species, and more species that were nesting, in areas with sheep excluded, compared to grazed areas. Two replicated site comparisons in desert and wetlands found higher abundances of some or all species of birds in areas with cattle or sheep excluded, compared to grazed areas. The wetland study also found lower abundances, in some comparisons.
Fish (2 studies): One replicated site comparison in grasslands in the USA found higher biomass and abundance of golden trout in areas with cattle excluded, compared to grazed areas. Another one found fewer trout nests in part of a stream with a livestock exclosure, compared to part without a livestock exclosure.
Invertebrates (5 studies): Two replicated studies (one randomized and controlled) in wetlands and grasslands in the USA found more species or families of invertebrates in areas with cattle excluded, compared to grazed areas, for some or all groups. One replicated, randomized, controlled study in grasslands in the USA found fewer aquatic invertebrate species in areas with cattle excluded, compared to grazed areas, in some comparisons. Two replicated studies (one randomized and controlled) in grasslands in the USA found no difference in invertebrate abundance between ungrazed and cattle-grazed plots. One replicated, before-and-after site comparison in grasslands in the USA found that populations of a threatened, endemic butterfly declined in sites with cattle excluded, but also declined in cattle-grazed sites.
Mammals (4 studies): Two replicated site comparisons in deserts and grasslands in Spain and the USA found more mammal species in areas with cattle or sheep excluded, compared to grazed areas. One of these studies also found higher mammal diversity, and both studies found higher mammal abundance, in areas with grazers excluded, compared to grazed areas, in some or all comparisons. One replicated site comparison in desert in the USA found lower abundances of black-tailed hares in ungrazed sites, compared to grazed sites, and one replicated, randomized, controlled study in wooded grassland in the USA found no difference in ground squirrel abundance between ungrazed plots and cattle-grazed plots.
Plants (41 studies)

Abundance (38 studies): Thirty-two studies (13 replicated, randomized, and controlled) in grasslands, shrublands, wetlands, deserts, and mixed habitats in the USA, Israel, Chile, Spain, and Australia found higher biomass, cover, or abundance of some or all plant groups (or lower cover of non-native species), in areas with cattle, sheep, goats, or alpacas excluded, compared to grazed areas, in some or all comparisons. Fourteen studies (four replicated, randomized and controlled) from the USA, Israel, Spain, and Australia found lower biomass, cover, or abundance of some or all plant groups (or higher cover of non-native species), in areas with grazers excluded, compared to grazed areas, in some comparisons. Five replicated, controlled studies (four randomized) in grasslands in the USA found no difference in the cover of plants (and/or non-native plants) between ungrazed and grazed areas.
Diversity (19 studies): Five studies (three replicated) in forests, shrublands, and grasslands in Israel, Spain, and the USA found more species, or fewer non-native species, in areas with cattle or sheep excluded, compared to grazed areas, in some or all comparisons. Nine studies in grasslands and shrublands in Australia, Israel, Spain, and the USA found fewer species or native species, larger decreases in the number of species, or smaller increases in the number of species, in areas with cattle, sheep, or alpacas excluded, compared to grazed areas, in some or all comparisons. Six studies in grasslands, wetlands, and deserts in the USA found no differences in the number of species between areas grazed by cattle, sheep, or alpacas, and ungrazed areas. Four studies in shrublands, grasslands, and wetlands in the USA and Israel found higher plant diversity, or different community composition, in plots with cattle excluded, compared to grazed plots, in some comparisons. Three studies in wetlands and grasslands in the USA found lower plant diversity in plots with cattle excluded, compared to grazed plots, in some comparisons. Three studies in deserts and shrublands in the USA and Israel found no difference in plant diversity between plots with cattle or sheep excluded and grazed plots. 
Survival (2 studies): One replicated, randomized, controlled study along creeks in the USA found that similar percentages of planted willows survived in pastures with or without cattle excluded. One replicated, randomized, controlled study in grasslands in the USA found higher plant survival in plots with cattle excluded, compared to grazed plots, in some comparisons.

Reptiles (1 study): One replicated site comparison in desert in the USA found lower abundances of reptiles, and of some reptile species, in areas with sheep excluded, compared to grazed areas, in some comparisons.
Implementation options (1 study): One site comparison in the USA found that more plant species were found in historically cultivated sites that were ungrazed, compared to grazed, but similar numbers of plant species were found in historically uncultivated sites that were ungrazed or grazed."
}
